{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3497419,"name":"Harrison","username":"hjmcphail76","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/hjmcphail76/{size}/234713_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-31T02:43:22.408Z","cooked":"

We are doing first tests of our thrifty elevator kit on our robot. After around 3-4 minutes of test cycles, we noticed the top sprockets were starting to scrape the top brace and the chain became ridiculously loose. Apparently, the rivets we put in the bearing mount to the 2x1 were starting to shear or bend. Admittedly, these were aluminum rivets and when we fix this we will use high strength rivets in a larger quantity. We also had not installed the top counter balance spring (it wasn’t in the video and the people assembling that part didn’t do it) so that might be it as well.

Has anyone else faced this issue with the thrifty elevator, or has any general suggestions? Will the proposed solutions of adding the spring and more and better rivets work as I am imagining? I just want some outside input from a fresh perspective. Here are some pictures:

IMG_71993024×4032 2.42 MB

IMG_71963024×4032 2.38 MB

IMG_72013024×4032 2.92 MB

IMG_72003024×4032 2.85 MB

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2025-01-31T02:43:22.408Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":41,"reads":217,"readers_count":216,"score":248.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":484418,"topic_slug":"thrifty-elevator-chain-issue","display_username":"Harrison","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":57833,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/thrifty-elevator-chain-issue/484418/1","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3497462,"name":"James Lyon","username":"Lyinlyon","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/lyinlyon/{size}/244534_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-31T02:56:03.134Z","cooked":"

I am not familiar with the thrifty elevator, but by the looks of it you may have overtightened the chain, casing the rivets to sheer. Definitely upgrade to steel rivets and maybe don’t put quite so much torque on the tensioner. I don’t think the spring has anything to do with it.

Hope this Helps!

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2025-01-31T02:56:03.134Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":182,"readers_count":181,"score":66.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":484418,"topic_slug":"thrifty-elevator-chain-issue","display_username":"James Lyon","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":71354,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"8410 Mechanical Lead "},"post_url":"/t/thrifty-elevator-chain-issue/484418/2","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3497471,"name":"Ryan Dognaux","username":"Ryan_Dognaux","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ryan_dognaux/{size}/129138_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-31T03:02:22.520Z","cooked":"

I’d add make sure the grip length of your rivets is correct too - if it’s not in the range of the combined thicknesses of material that you’re going through they won’t work as well. Steel 3/16 rivets or even a bolt or two if you’re really pulling a lot of weight should prevent this.

We have found that it does the same on ours. We have 9 bolts holding it, still pushes down, we saw this at the competition. Looks like people just wait for it to get to lowest point and adjust their chains. What did you do?

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2025-03-24T23:54:48.975Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":93,"readers_count":92,"score":23.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":484418,"topic_slug":"thrifty-elevator-chain-issue","display_username":"P.D","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":57101,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/thrifty-elevator-chain-issue/484418/4","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3567554,"name":"Harrison","username":"hjmcphail76","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/hjmcphail76/{size}/234713_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-25T00:03:24.571Z","cooked":"

So we used 9 high strength rivets… on top of that, we put bolts through the cross brace under those brackets that act as a “jack” to take stress off it. More or a preventative act, not sure if it’s helpful, but no issues since.
![IMG_7594|375x500](upload://8VjiLyWpdLprPmXTTqXk0insn1q.jp

IMG_77441170×854 201 KB

We have experienced this same issue with our TTB elevator. The bracket started slopping down shortly after use. We fastened it with 10-32 screws and the hole in the box tube was a standard 0.201" free-fit hole. We have had the chain come off in practice due to the sprocket teeth getting chiseled in half.

Eventually it got to the point where it stopped destroying the teeth beyond a certain extent, but as a precaution we milled out a slot in the tube it was scraping against so it has no chance of getting worse.

We stopped the chain from coming off by just tensioning the chain harder.

I kinda wish there was a more obvious warning of this issue because I thought it was only us until reading this thread just now.

A Ø.201 hole is pretty loose for a 3/16" rivet.
I doubt you are getting enough compression from a rivet to handle the chain tension, normal elevator movements, and the shock loads seen by most elevators.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2025-03-25T01:01:30.358Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":53,"readers_count":52,"score":10.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":484418,"topic_slug":"thrifty-elevator-chain-issue","display_username":"tim-tim","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":8037,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/thrifty-elevator-chain-issue/484418/8","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3567648,"name":"Harrison","username":"hjmcphail76","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/hjmcphail76/{size}/234713_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-25T01:11:59.441Z","cooked":"

IMG_76124032×3024 2.29 MB

One thing I suggest is making the crossbrace be longer and go OVER the stage vertical tubes. Shouldn’t cause an issue if your not crashing your elevator, but it adds some rigidity.ours was shearing the rivets and was bending a small bit

image850×563 111 KB

The bearing support bar kept moving which would loosen the chain. This 3D printed support in the middle of shaft worked surprisingly well. Installed a similar solution at the bottom shaft.
